ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (BNY Mellon)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC")
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC Staff alleged violations of Sections 13(b)(2)(A) & (B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for books and records and internal regulatory accounting control deficiencies in connection with the calculation of risk-based regulatory capital ratios presented in annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A civil money penalty in the amount of $6,600,000 was ordered to be paid by BNY Mellon. BNY Mellon will effect payment on a date TBD.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon - London Branch (BNYM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.K. Financial Conduct Authority
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority alleged that BNYM failed to comply with certain rules set forth in the U.K. Clients Assets Sourcebook, which sets forth the regime in the U.K. for the protection of client interests.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: BNY Mellon entered into a settlement agreement with the UK Financial Conduct Authority (the "FCA") on March 6, 2015, and the FCA issued its Final Notice, in which the 126 million pounds (approx. $188M) fine was imposed, on April 14, 2015.

ENTITYNAME: Dreyfus Service Organization, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: Proceeding by the Commissioner of Banking and Ins. State of NJ Ref. No. 8059711
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, Trenton, New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged that Dreyfus Service Organization ("DSO") between June 2002 and November 2002 "caused, permitted or was otherwise responsible for allowing an employee to solicit and write eight New Jersey annuity contracts without the benefit of a current license." DSO had an employee with a non-resident NJ insurance license which had expired and was later reinstated. The sales were made during the period when the employee's license was inactive, although DSO had reason to believe the license was, in fact, active. Without admitting or denying any violation of the insurance statutes or regulations or any wrongdoing, DSO consented to an administrative sanction in the amount of $4000.00 to fully and completely resolve the matter.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(d)(4)(v) above.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufscht -Germany
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufscht (the BaFin), the financial supervisory authority in Germany, alleged that The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (BNY Mellon) violated certain supervisory duties under the Securities Trading Act (the Act). Under this Act, anyone whose shareholding in a German issuer reaches, exceeds or falls below 3%, 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 30%, 50% or 75% of the voting rights shall notify the issuer and the BaFin, without undue delay, and within four trading days at the latest. The BaFin alleged that: (1) notifications sent by BNY Mellon on behalf of certain subsidiaries to a German issuer and the BaFin of the reduction of its voting shares in the issuer below the 3% threshold was one month late and (2) BNY Mellon failed to take the supervisory measures required under the Act to prevent contravention of the shareholding notice obligations by its subsidiaries. On May 12, 2011, the BaFin issued an administrative order that: (1) determined that BNY Mellon negligently failed to comply with the supervisory requirements with respect to its subsidiaries in order to ensure compliance with the notification deadlines and (2) imposed against BNY Mellon an administrative fine of EUR 22,500.00 (approx. $31,725) and a fee (for procedural costs) of EUR 1,125.00 (approx. $1,586). BNY Mellon made payment effective May 27, 2011.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See response in 10(f)(v)

ENTITYNAME: CIBC Mellon Trust Company
ACTIONTITLE: U.S. Securitities and Exchange Commission v. CIBC Mellon Trust Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC")
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: CIBC Mellon Trust Company ("CMTC"), a transfer agent that is an affiliate of Registrant by virtue of Mellon Canada Holding Company's 50 percent interest in the joint venture, submitted a Consent to Entry of Judgment (the "Consent"), which was presented by the SEC in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (the "Court") on February 16, 2005. In the Consent, and solely for the purpose of the injunctive action and any other proceedings arising out of the SEC's investigation brought by or on behalf of the SEC or to which the SEC is a party, CMTC consented to the entry of Final Judgment as to Defendant CMTC (the "Final Judgment") without admitting or denying the matters set forth therein (other than those relating to the jurisdiction of the Court and the subject matter of the action). The Final Judgment, entered on Feb. 24, 2005, resolved the allegations that CMTC had failed to register as a transfer agent with the SEC, that it had issued "legend free" stock certificates of a company whose shares were not registered with the SEC, that one of its managers had accepted payments of stock from that company's officers to issue the certificates, and that it had acted as an unregistered broker or dealer in connection with its stock plan administration business. CMTC was permanently enjoined from prescribed violations of Securities Act Section 5, Exchange Act Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, Exchange Act Section 15(a), Exchange Act Section 17A(c)(1), and from aiding and abetting future violations of Exchange Act Section 10(b) or Rule 10b-5. CMTC also agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $5 million and disgorgement of $889,773 and prejudgment interest of $140,270. Payment was made on March 4, 2005. CMTC also consented, without admitting or denying the SEC complaint's allegations, to the entry of an SEC administrative order based on the Final Judgment on March 2, 2005 (the "Order"). Pursuant to the Order, CMTC was censured and agreed to an undertaking to engage an independent consultant to review its relevant businesses and procedures. This matter responds to items 10B(1) and 10C(2).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Entry of Judgment on consent. See item (v) above for detail.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon (the Bank)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC")
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On June 13, 2016, the SEC finalized a settlement with the Bank, an affiliate of the Registrant, relating to the Bank's standing instruction foreign exchange ("FX") program. The SEC instituted a settled administrative proceeding against the Bank, finding that the Bank violated Section 34(b) of the Investment Company Act of 1940, and caused violations of Section 31(a) of the act and Rule 31a-1(b) thereunder. The order requires the Bank to cease and desist from such violations, pay a $30 million civil penalty, and disgorge $133,022,207 which is deemed satisfied by the Bank's prior payments in related settlements with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and The New York Attorney General. The order also requires the Bank to report on its remediation and implementation of compliance measures relating to its standing instruction FX programs offered to registered investment adviser custodial clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(1)(v) above.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon (BNYM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System ("BGFRS")
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On 9/22/08, BNYM borrowed from the Boston Federal Reserve Bank under the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility ("AMLF") program. It was alleged that due to a failure in its internal processes at the time, a portion of the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper ("ABCP") collateral pledged by BNYM was ineligible under the terms of the AMLF. As a result, BNYM received more in the AMLF loans proceeds than it otherwise would have been advanced, based upon the eligible ABCP collateral pledged.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The BGFRS and BNYM have mutually agreed to enter into a combined Order to Cease & Desist and Order of Assessment of a Civil Monetary Penalty of $6,000,000.

DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that from at least January 1, 2003 through June 30, 2004, in connection with certain auctions, The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank on New York) ("BNY") accepted initial or revised bids after submission deadlines and allowed broker-dealers to intervene in auctions. In certain instances, this conduct also affected the rate paid on the auction rate securities. As a result, BNY caused violations of section 17(a)(2) of the Securities Act. BNY was required to make certain disclosures regarding its material auction practices and procedures; and not later than 6 months after the date of this order, unless otherwise extended by the Staff of the Commission for good cause shown, have its CEO or General Counsel certify in writing to the Staff of the Commission that BNY has implemented procedures. In addition, BNY paid a monetary settlement in the amount of $750,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: Franklin Templeton Asset Management (India) Private Limited
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SEBI issued a finding that an Indian-domiciled mutual fund was not operated in accordance with the SEBI regulations that stipulate the form of the fund's investment committee (IC) and require that the fund carry out all of its operations, including location of IC members, within India. In connection with that finding, SEBI imposed a penalty on the fund, fund's trustee company and the adviser as manager of the fund in the amount of approximately US$14,672 (the equivalent of the INR amount as of the date of payment) which was paid by the adviser on behalf of all parties.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SEBI imposed a penalty on the fund, fund's trustee company and the adviser as manager of the fund of INR 1,000,000 (approximately US$14,672 as of date of payment) was paid by the adviser on behalf of all the parties to resolve the matter on 11/29/2016.

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SFC issued a public censure of TAML in connection with its finding that TAML breached Rule 22 of the Hong Kong Takeovers Code as a result of TAML's inadvertent failure to disclose its dealings in the shares of a Hong Kong company between January 26, 2010 and April 15, 2010.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Resolved. TAML cooperated wit the SFC and consented to the censure in connection with its inadvertent failure to make disclosures required by the Takeovers Code. TAML publicly disclosed its holdings but missed the additional code requirements.

ENTITYNAME: Security Benefit Life Insurance Company (SBL)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Alabama Department of Insurance (ADI)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On 4/4/2006, the ADI entered an Order to Show Cause against SBL regarding its failure to pay an invoice for agent appointment fees dated 1/2/2006. SBL paid outstanding invoice on 4/13/2006, and remitted a letter to the ADI explaining its non-payment was not a willful violation of ADI Regulations.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On 5/17/2006, the ADI entered an Order Lifting Order to Show Cause and Settlement Agreement. SBL consented to a $500 fine and agreed to promptly pay invoices for the continuation of producer appointments in the future.

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Texas State Securities Board
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: In May 2015, the Staff of the Texas Securities Board initiated an investigation into LPL's Financial Statement Reviews for agents registered with the Texas Securities Commission. In certain instances, during the relevant periods of January 2011 through September 2011 and June 2014 through December 2014, the Financial Statement Reviews were not conducted in accordance with LPL's written supervisory procedures.

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Washington Insurance Commissioner
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the entry of a consent order with the Insurance Commissioner of the state of Washington, after its investigation into the conduct of a non-resident insurance producer after receiving a complaint from an insured alleging that he misrepresented the benefits and suitability of an annuity. More than one of the insurance producers' violations were known or should have been known by one or more individuals acting on behalf of LPL, and LPL neither reported the violations nor took corrective action.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LPL paid a fine in the amount of $2,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Firm entered into a Consent Order with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Enforcement Section of the Division, related to their investigation into whether the Firm's activities and conduct violated the Massachusetts Uniform Securities Act. The Enforcement Section alleged that during the time period of January 1, 2014 to June 30, 2016, the Firm failed to supervise its agents when it failed to review those agents' misleading communications with the public in connection with the purchase and sale of an agents' book of business. The Enforcement Section also alleged that the Firm failed to supervise its agents when such agent borrowed money from a client and lost that money in speculative trading for agents' own account.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A fine in the amount of $100,000.00, payment of restitution to clients in the amount of $217,750.00, cease and desist, additional undertakings of employee training, and changes to policies and procedures.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, LPL Financial LLC ("The Firm") consented to the sanctions and to the entry of findings that it failed to send and create records that it had sent to customers, more than 1.6 million account notices required under Rule 17a-3(a)(17) of the Exchange Act. The Firm is required to send these account notices to customers at 36 month intervals for each account in which a suitability determination was made. Over a seven-year period, the Firm failed to send over 25 percent of the required notices. In addition, the Firm failed to establish, maintain, and enforce a supervisory system and written supervisory procedures reasonably designed to achieve compliance with applicable laws and regulations in relation to the creation and distribution of such account records.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The firm was censured, fined $900,000.00, and consented to additional undertakings to review policies and procedures.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the findings that from January 1, 2008 through December 31,2013, it failed to implement an adequate supervisory system regarding its sales of non-traded REITs and failed to enforce its written procedures regarding the sale of non-traded REITs to Hawaii residents.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil penalty in the amount of $19,825.37, cease and desist, offers of remediation, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Montana Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the findings that from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2013, it failed to implement an adequate supervisory system regarding its sales of non-traded REITs and failed to enforce its written procedures regarding the sale of non-traded REITs to Montana residents.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil penalty in the amount of $11,397.81, investigative costs of $29,112.18, cease and desist, offers of remediation, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, LPL Financial LLC ("The Firm") consented to the sanctions and to the entry of findings that it failed to maintain over 18.3 million electronic communications in non-erasable and no re-writable format, known as WORM ("write once, read many") format. The findings stated that the WORM format is intended to prevent the alteration or destruction of broker dealer records maintained on electronic storage media. In addition, the Firm failed to retain check registers in WORM format. The findings also stated that the Firm's written supervisory procedures failed to have an adequate supervisory process concerning WORM compliance.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The firm was censured and fined $750,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Firm entered into a Consent Order with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Enforcement Section of the Division, related to allegations that LPL advisor, Roger S. Zullo, fabricated the suitability profiles of numerous LPL clients, selling them scores of large, illiquid, unsuitable, high commission variable annuities, at substantial upfront profits to himself and LPL, in violation of Sections 101, 102, and 204(a)(2)(G) of the Act. The Enforcement Section further alleges that LPL failed in its responsibility to supervise Roger S. Zullo, in violation of Section 204(a)(2)(J).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Cease and desist, censure, a fine in the amount of $975,000.00, additional undertakings, restitution and disgorgement to be determined based on results of LPL Financials investigation and accounting.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Kentucky
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL paid advisory compensation to a registered representative who was not qualified and was not registered as an investment advisor representative.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Ohio Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL failed to report various regulatory actions to the Ohio Department of Insurance within 30 days.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: $800.00 fine and investigative costs of $200.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Texas
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Involved allegations with LPL failed to timely update its Form BD to reflect the use of other business names in connection with securities activity by certain LPL branch offices in TX.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The order resulted in a reprimand and a fine in the amount of $10,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegations of failure to supervise and train registered representatives in connection with the sale of non-traded REITS.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in a fine of $500,000.00 and restitution to certain customers.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Texas
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The state alleged that LPL failed to enforce its written procedures by failing to report a felony charge on a registered representative's Form U4.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL submitted to a consent order with the Illinois Securities Department in connection with certain variable annuity exchange transactions, in particular, relating to its failure to adequately enforce supervisory procedures and maintain certain books and records required under Illinois law.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LPL agreed to a censure, fine of $2,000,000.00 and restitution to impacted customers of approximately $800,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL Financial failed to detect improper and fraudulent conduct on the part of David Lisnek toward his LPL clients. LPL Financial allowed Mr. Lisnek to remain a registered representative while several facts, viewed together as a pattern of conduct, would have constituted multiple cautionary indicators of the potential for improper conduct.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $500,000.00 and restitution in the amount of $315,218.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Securities Division
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the findings that it did not establish, maintain, or enforce adequate procedures to review senior-specific titles for compliance with the Commonwealth's Senior Designations Regulations adopted June 1, 2007. As a result, LPL allowed its broker-dealer agents and investment adviser representatives to use prohibited senior-specific designations.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Censure, undertakings, cease and desist, and a fine in the amount of $250,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Florida Office of Financial Regulation
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of the findings that from September 2009 to September 2013, LPL allowed one of its registered representatives to engage in investment advisory business from an office in the State of Florida without being lawfully registered in Florida.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Cease and desist and a fine in the amount of $10,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Delaware Investor Protection Unit
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that LPL failed to ensure that its financial advisors understood and explained the unique risks, failed to enforce its warning and fine system with regard to its leveraged ETFs concentration limits, and failed to adequately monitor and ensure the monitoring of client holding periods, all of which constitute a failure to supervise.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine in the amount of $50,000.00, restitution in the amount of $150,000.00, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Nevada Securities Division
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2013, LPL offered multiple non-traded REITs that were sold in excess of the REIT's prospectus standards, various state concentration limits, or its own alternative investment guidelines. LPL failed to implement an adequate supervisory system that was reasonably designed to achieve compliance with NAC 90.321. LPL also failed to enforce its written procedures to supervise the activities of its registered representatives in violation of NAC 90.321.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $21,202.19 and reimbursement of $19,676.00 for investigation costs to Nevada, reimbursement of $35,000.00 for investigation costs to NASAA, censure, restitution, cease and desist, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Puerto Rico
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the findings that from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2013, it failed to implement an adequate supervisory system regarding its sales of non-traded REITs and failed to enforce its written procedures regarding the sale of non-traded REITs to Puerto Rico residents.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil penalty in the amount of $10,125.11, cease and desist, offers of remediation, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that LPL offered leveraged ETFs without monitoring and systematically reviewing the length of time its clients held leveraged ETFs. LPL provided insufficient training materials to financial advisors and failed to identify and examine potential issues concerning the suitability of leveraged ETF exposure. Moreover, LPL did not consistently adhere to its policy of imposing fines on LPL financial advisors who exceeded this concentration limit.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine in the amount of $200,000.00, restitution in the amount of $1,600,000.00, and undertakings.

DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil penalty in the amount of $1,800.00 and administrative costs of $200.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Montana
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to reasonably supervise a former registered representative.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Consent order resulted in LPL agreeing to pay restitution of $1,144,416.51 and a fine to the State of MT of $150,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to detect role of one of its former representatives in the sale of participations in oil and gas projects.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in a $300,000.00 fine and restitution of $167,796.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to supervise a former registered representative.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in $1,885,000.00 restitution to customers.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Pennsylvania
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to supervise two former registered representatives.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in $59,092.52 fine for investigative costs.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Oregon
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to supervise a former OSJ manager's transactions.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in $100,000.00 fine.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Missouri
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Matter involved sale of variable annuity contract in which a registered representative allegedly misunderstood the contract's rider.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Matter resulted in a censure and $37,540.00 in total for fine, restitution and interest.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Pennsylvania
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegations that at certain times between 1998 and 2006, LPL failed to maintain or enforce procedures reasonably designed to supervise one or more of its former registered representatives.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The matter resulted in a $200,000.00 administrative assessment and $30,000.00 for investigative and legal costs.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegations of failure to supervise and train registered representatives in connection with the sale of non-traded REITS.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $500,000.00 and restitution to certain customers.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Texas
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The state alleged that LPL failed to enforce its written procedures relating to the notification of a felony charge and Form U4 updates.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Missouri
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to supervise a former registered representative.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $175,000.00 and payment of the cost of the investigation in the amount of $10,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Montana
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Allegation that LPL failed to supervise a former registered representative.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $10,000.00 and $20,500.00 in restitution to customers.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL submitted to a consent order with the Illinois Securities Department in connection with certain variable annuity exchange transactions, in particular, relating to its failure to adequately enforce supervisory procedures and maintain certain books and records required under Illinois law.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LPL agreed to a censure, fine of $2,000,000.00 and restitution to impacted customers of approximately $800,000.00

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Ohio Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL failed to report various regulatory actions to the Ohio Department of Insurance within 30 days.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: $800.00 fine and investigative costs of $200.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Illinois Securities Department
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL Financial failed to detect improper and fraudulent conduct on the part of David Lisnek toward his LPL clients. LPL Financial allowed Mr. Lisnek to remain a registered representative while several facts, viewed together as a pattern of conduct, would have constituted multiple cautionary indicators of the potential for improper conduct.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $500,000.00 and restitution in the amount of $315,218.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Securities Division
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the findings that it did not establish, maintain, or enforce adequate procedures to review senior-specific titles for compliance with the Commonwealth's Senior Designations Regulations adopted June 1, 2007. As a result, LPL allowed its broker-dealer agents and investment adviser representatives to use prohibited senior-specific designations.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Censure, undertakings, cease and desist, and a fine in the amount of $250,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Florida Office of Financial Regulation
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of the findings that from September 2009 to September 2013, LPL allowed one of its registered representatives to engage in investment advisory business from an office in the State of Florida without being lawfully registered in Florida.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Cease and desist and a fine in the amount of $10,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Delaware Investor Protection Unit
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that LPL failed to ensure that its financial advisors understood and explained the unique risks, failed to enforce its warning and fine system with regard to its leveraged ETFs concentration limits, and failed to adequately monitor and ensure the monitoring of client holding periods, all of which constitute a failure to supervise.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine in the amount of $50,000, restitution in the amount of $150,000.00, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Nevada Securities Division
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that from January 1, 2008 through December 31, 2013, LPL offered multiple non-traded REITs that were sold in excess of the REIT's prospectus standards, various state concentration limits, or its own alternative investment guidelines. LPL failed to implement an adequate supervisory system that was reasonably designed to achieve compliance with NAC 90.321. LPL also failed to enforce its written procedures to supervise the activities of its registered representatives in violation of NAC 90.321.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine of $21,202.19 and reimbursement of $19,676.00 for investigation costs to Nevada, reimbursement of $35,000.00 for investigation costs to NASAA, censure, restitution, cease and desist, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the sanctions and the entry of findings that LPL offered leveraged ETFs without monitoring and systematically reviewing the length of time its clients held leveraged ETFs. LPL provided insufficient training materials to financial advisors and failed to identify and examine potential issues concerning the suitability of leveraged ETF exposure. Moreover, LPL did not consistently adhere to its policy of imposing fines on LPL financial advisors who exceeded this concentration limit.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Fine in the amount of $200,000.00, restitution in the amount of $1,600,000.00, and undertakings.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Ohio Department of Insurance
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: LPL consented to the allegations that it violated Ohio statute 3905.22 by failing to timely report a regulatory action taken by the state of New Hampshire dated April 6, 2015.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Civil fine in the amount of $1,800.00 and administrative costs of $200.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Firm entered into a Consent Order with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Enforcement Section of the Division, related to their investigation into whether the Firm's activities and conduct violated the Massachusetts Uniform Securities Act. The Enforcement Section alleged that during the time period of January 1, 2014 to June 30, 2016, the Firm failed to supervise its agents when it failed to review those agents' misleading communications with the public in connection with the purchase and sale of an agents' book of business. The Enforcement Section also alleged that the Firm failed to supervise its agents when such agent borrowed money from a client and lost that money in speculative trading for agents' own account.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A fine in the amount of $100,000.00, payment of restitution to clients in the amount of $217,750.00, cease and desist, additional undertakings of employee training, and changes to policies and procedures.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, LPL Financial LLC ("The Firm") consented to the sanctions and to the entry of findings that it failed to maintain over 18.3 million electronic communications in non-erasable and no re-writable format, known as WORM ("write once, read many") format. The findings stated that the WORM format is intended to prevent the alteration or destruction of broker dealer records maintained on electronic storage media. In addition, the Firm failed to retain check registers in WORM format. The findings also stated that the Firm's written supervisory procedures failed to have an adequate supervisory process concerning WORM compliance.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The firm was censured and fined $750,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, LPL Financial LLC ("The Firm") consented to the sanctions and to the entry of findings that it failed to send and create records that it had sent to customers, more than 1.6 million account notices required under Rule 17a-3(a)(17) of the Exchange Act. The Firm is required to send these account notices to customers at 36 month intervals for each account in which a suitability determination was made. Over a seven-year period, the Firm failed to send over 25 percent of the required notices. In addition, the Firm failed to establish, maintain, and enforce a supervisory system and written supervisory procedures reasonably designed to achieve compliance with applicable laws and regulations in relation to the creation and distribution of such account records.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The firm was censured, fined $900,000.00, and consented to additional undertakings to review policies and procedures.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial LLC
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Commonwealth of Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Firm entered into a Consent Order with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Enforcement Section of the Division, related to allegations that LPL advisor, Roger S. Zullo, fabricated the suitability profiles of numerous LPL clients, selling them scores of large, illiquid, unsuitable, high commission variable annuities, at substantial upfront profits to himself and LPL, in violation of Sections 101, 102, and 204(a)(2)(G) of the Act. The Enforcement Section further alleges that LPL failed in its responsibility to supervise Roger S. Zullo, in violation of Section 204(a)(2)(J).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Cease and desist, censure, a fine in the amount of $975,000.00, additional undertakings, restitution and disgorgement to be determined based on results of LPL Financials investigation and accounting.

DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: LPL did not receive the invoice for the $1,000 civil penalty and administrative costs. When the Firm became aware of the Order of Revocation, the monetary penalty was paid promptly and the Firm's license was reinstated on February 27, 2015.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Beginning in 2007, LPL pursued a strategy of significantly increasing the size of the Firm but LPL did not accompany this rapid growth with a concomitant dedication of sufficient resources to permit the Firm to meet its supervisory obligations. As a result, the Firm failed to have adequate systems and procedures in place to supervise certain aspects of its business. Examples of the alleged failures stemming from these allegations are set forth in the AWC, number 2013035109701.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: $10,000,000 fine, undertakings, and restitution to certain customers.

ENTITYNAME: LPL Financial
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Without admitting or denying the findings, the Firm consented to the sanctions and to the entry of findings that it disadvantaged certain retirement plan and charitable organization customers who were eligible to purchase Class A shares in certain mutual funds without a front-end sales charge. The findings stated that these customers were instead sold Class A shares with a front-end sales charge or a Class B or C shares with back-end sales charges and higher ongoing fees and expenses. These sales disadvantaged customers by causing them to pay higher fees than they were actually required to pay. The findings also stated that the Firm has failed to establish and maintain a supervisory system and procedures reasonably designed to ensure that customers who purchased mutual fund shares received the benefit of applicable sales charge waivers. The Firm also failed to adopt any controls to detect instances in which the Firm did not provide sales charge waivers to customers in connection with their mutual fund purchases.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Censure, undertakings, and $5.72 million in restitution to customers.

ENTITYNAME: American Skandia Investment Services, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of American Skandia Investment Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Attorney General of the State of New York, NY
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The New York Attorney General alleged that ASISI violated the Martin Act (Article 23-a of the General Business Law), General Business law Section 349 and Executive Law Section 63 (12). The allegations concerned market-timing related activities that occurred generally between 1998 and September 2003 by ASISI as adviser to the funds. The allegations also concerned non-disclosure of these market-timing activities and related conflicts.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: This action, as well as a similar action by the SEC, was settled without ASlSl admitting or denying the findings.

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, Washington, D.C.

ENTITYNAME: Prudential Financial, Inc. and one or more affiliates
ACTIONTITLE: Securities and Exchange Commission v. Prudential Financial, Inc. et al.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC filed a compliant alleging that Prudential Financial Inc. improperly accounted for certain reinsurance contracts entered into with a single counterparty in the years 1997-2002 relating to the Company's property and casualty operations that were sold in 2003. The Compliant alleges that this resulted in an overstatement of the Company's consolidated results for certain years in report filed with SEC, in violation of the financial reporting, books and records and internal control provisions of the Exchange Act.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, the Company consented to the entry of final judgment enjoining it from future violations of specified provisions of the Exchange Act and related rules and regulations of the SEC thereunder.

ENTITYNAME: ALPS Fund Services, Inc.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The auditor violated the SEC's auditor independence rules. AFS provides compliance related services to the funds, by furnishing a CCO to the funds who, consistent with Rule 38a-1 under the Investment Act of 1940, administered the funds' compliance policies and procedures. The SEC found that the funds did not adopt sufficient additional written policies and procedures reasonably designed to prevent violation of the SAC's auditor independent rules.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the findings, AFS settled charges that it caused the funds to violate Rule 38a-1. AFS agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $45,000.

DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Applicant submitted an undertaking to the Division in association wit the Applicant's registration as a Broker/Dealer. The Division issued an order of Reinstatement of Applicant Broker/Dealer effective May 1, 1990.

ENTITYNAME: ALPS Distributors, Inc.

ADI consented to the entry of the AWC without admitting or denying the findings.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: ADI has implemented procedures to address the issues identified in the AWC. AFS agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $45,000.

ENTITYNAME: UMB Bank, N.A. Investment Banking Division
ACTIONTITLE: Order Instituting Administrative and Cease-and-Desist Proceedings Pursuant to Se
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U. S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: This matter involves violations of an antifraud provision of the Federal Securities Laws in connection with UMB Bank, N.A. Investment Banking Division's ('Respondent') underwriting of certain municipal securities offerings.  The Respondent is a Control Affiliate of the Registrant and Registrant was not a party to this action.  Respondent conducted inadequate due diligence in certain offerings and as a result, failed to form a reasonable basis for believing the truthfulness of certain material representations in official statements issued in connection with those offerings.  This resulted in respondent offering and selling municipal securities on the basis of materially misleading disclosure documents.  Respondent self-reported these violations to the U. S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC') pursuant to the municipalities continuing disclosure cooperation ('MCDC') initiative.            Respondent voluntarily participated in the MCDC initiative and is one of at least 58 firms that entered into a settlement with the SEC regarding these issues.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Respondent submitted an offer of settlement to the SEC, which the SEC determined to accept.  Solely for the purpose of these proceedings and any other proceedings brought by or on behalf of the SEC, or to which the SEC is a party, and without admitting or

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of Missouri Office of Secretary of State.
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: UMB Financial Services, Inc. is a Control Affiliate of the Registrant and Registrant was not a party to this action.  This consent order related to the State of Missouri's Securities Division's (the 'Division') finding of facts that led the Division to believe UMB Financial Services Inc.'s conduct and documentation relating to a UMB Financial Services Inc.'s representative's special supervision were inadequate, that procedures pertaining to transmittal of an IRA rollover were not followed and that UMB Financial Services Inc. did not require the prioritization of investment objectives.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: On September 12, 2008 UMB Financial Services, Inc. stipulated to a consent order and agreed to pay to the State of Missouri's Education and Protection Fund $30,000 and costs of the investigation of $13,000.  No penalties or fines were imposed against UMB

COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Bank of Italy
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Bank of Italy found deficiencies relating to internal controls, recordkeeping (missing or inadequate documentation), and asset valuation.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The Bank of Italy imposed fines against SSB Sp and certain of its officers for a total of 116,000 euro.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Trust and Banking Co., Ltd. (Japan) (SSTB Japan)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Financial Services Agency (Japan)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: FSA issued an Administrative Order requiring SSTB Japan to implement certain improvements to its local management structure and operations.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSTB (Japan) implemented the improvements and on February 6, 2007, the FSA lifted the Administrative Order.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company - Tokyo Branch (SSBT Tokyo)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Financial Services Agency (Japan)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: FSA issued an Administrative Order requiring SSBT Tokyo Branch to implement certain improvements to its local internal controls for Japanese regulatory compliance in connection with its securities lending business.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT Tokyo Branch implemented the improvements and on February 6, 2007, the FSA lifted the Administrative Order.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company - Seoul Branch (SSBT Seoul)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Korea Financial Supervisory Service (FSS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: FSS issued an Administrative Order suspending foreign trades for thirty days after an examination determined that SSBT Seoul previously booked certain intra branch foreign exchange transactions.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The thirty day suspension was completed and the matter has been terminated.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Advisors Limited (SSgA Ltd.)
ACTIONTITLE: Stichting Pensioenfonds OPG v. SSgA Ltd.
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: District Court of Amsterdam, the Netherlands
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Plaintiff invested in an SSgA managed common trust fund that utilized a Lehman entity as prime broker. Plaintiff claimed SSgA Ltd. was liable for its losses arising from Lehmans insolvency.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Court ruled that SSgA Ltd was liable to plaintiff for loss arising from Lehman insolvency.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank Europe Limited, State Street Global Markets International Limited
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: UK Financial Conduct Authority
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The FCA issued a Final Notice relating to State Street having overcharged six clients of its UK transition management business during 2010 and 2011. The FCA found violations of three of its principles for businesses relating to controls, the fair treatment of clients in the wholesale markets, and customer communications (Principles 3, 6, and 7).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The FCA imposed a financial penalty of 22,885,000 pounds and ordered the disgorgement and repayment of the undisclosed commissions.

ENTITYNAME: SSgM Canada Inc. (SSGMC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Autorite des Marches Financiers (AMF)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGMC was cited for failure to file annual disclosures for years 2005 and 2007 within the required timeframe.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGMC paid a $30,000 fine.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Advisors Asia Limited (SSgAA)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSgAA was cited for its failure to comply with requirements related to receipt of interest on Hong Kong dollar cash balances.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSgAA paid a fine of approximately $500,000, paid approximately $40,000 to the affected fund, and agreed to an independent review of cash management policies and procedures for SFC authorized funds.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to certain fixed income investments strategies managed by SSBT.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings. SSBT agreed to pay $10 million to each of MA SOS and MA Attorney General.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Office of Foreign Assets Control
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: OFAC asserted that SSBT had not filed certain OFAC reports for 1997-2000 under 31 CFR 501-805(d)(1)
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT resolved this matter and paid $22,000

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to certain fixed income investment strategies managed by SSBT.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings.  SSBT agreed to pay $10 million to each of MA SOS and MA Attorney General.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to a collateralized debt obligation, or CDO, transaction (Carina CDO, Ltd.) for which SSBT acted as collateral manager.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings. SSBT agreed to pay $5 million to MA SOS.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to a collateralized debt obligation, or CDO, transaction for which SSBT acted as collateral manager.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings. SSBT agreed to pay $5 million to MA SOS.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: US Department of Justice
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The Department of Justice entered into an agreement with SSBT to settle allegations that SSBT had violated the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 in connection with its pricing of certain foreign currency exchange services during the 2003-2009 period.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT admitted certain facts concerning its FX pricing practices, but neither admitted nor denied the allegations, and paid a civil penalty in the amount of $155 million.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: US Department of Labor
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Department of Labor entered into an agreement with SSBT to settle allegations that SSBT had violated certain fiduciary duties under ERISA and engaged in certain prohibited transactions in connection with its pricing of certain foreign currency exchange services for ERISA Plans and Group Trust Plans during the 1998-2009 period.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the allegations, and agreed to pay a civil penalty in the amount of $12 million and restitution in the amount of $60 million.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of State Street Bank and Trust Company (FX)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Attorney General (MASS AG)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSBT entered into an agreement with the MASS AG to resolve allegations that SSBT had violated the states Consumer Protection Act in connection with its pricing of certain foreign currency trades during the 2006-2009 period.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT admitted certain facts concerning its FX pricing practices, but neither admitted nor denied the allegations, and made a payment in the amount of $500,000 to the MASS AG to reimburse investigation costs.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets LLC (SSGM)
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of State Street Global Markets LLC (Expenses)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MASD)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On December 12, 2016, SSGM entered into an agreement with the MASD to settle an administrative complaint alleging expense invoices of SSGM or its affiliates violated state law.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGM neither admitted nor denied the allegations.  SSGM made a payment of $2.5 million.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Corporation (SSC)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: US Department of Justice (US DOJ)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On January 18, 2017, SSC entered into a Deferred Prosecution Agreement with the US Attorneys Office (Massachusetts) and the US DOJ to resolve allegations that SSC had engaged in a conspiracy to commit wire fraud and securities fraud in violation of Title 18, US Code, Section 371. The allegations arose in connection with an investigation of the overcharging of six clients by certain State Street Bank employees.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSC admitted the underlying facts, paid a fine of $32.3 million, and agreed to certain undertakings. The charge will be dismissed in 3 years if SSC complies with the Agreement terms during the deferral period.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to certain fixed income investment strategies managed by SSBT.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings. SSBT agreed to pay $10 million to each of MA SOS and MA Attorney General.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Massachusetts Secretary of State Securities Division (MA SOS)
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: MA SOS issued consent order finding that SSBT violated MGL c. 110A, Sec. 101(2) and 101(3) as to disclosures relating to a collateralized debt obligation, or CDO, transaction for which SSBT acted as collateral manager.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT neither admitted nor denied the findings. SSBT agreed to pay $5 million to MA SOS.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to accept certain trades within 20 minute requirement.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent and paid a $5,000.00 fine.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD, Boston, Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for submitting OATS reports not in prescribed electronic form, transmitting OATS reports containing inaccurate data, and failing to timely file ROES.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $40,000.00.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD, Boston, Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for reporting certain long and short sale transactions to ACT with the incorrect modifier.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent and paid a $2,500.00 fine.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD, Boston, Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to report into ACT certain transactions within 90 seconds after execution and certain last sale reports.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent and paid a $5,000.00 fine.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for reporting certain transactions to OATS containing inaccurate, incomplete or improperly formatted data, failing to accept or decline certain eligible securities within 20 minutes after execution.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, paid a $20,000.00 fine and updated and enhanced its supervisory procedures.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD, Boston, Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to report corporate bond transactions to TRACE and municipal bond transactions to MSRB, and failure to maintain adequate supervisory system, procedures and training.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $1,400,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASD, Boston, Massachusetts
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to maintain and preserve all business related instant messages (IM) and failing to maintain adequate supervisory system, procedures and training related to IMs.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $100,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for providing incomplete information in a report regarding covered orders in national market securities that it received for execution from any person.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $15,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to record the time of trade execution for transactions in TRACE.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $27,500.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of State Street Bank and Trust Company (FX)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SEC issued an administrative cease and desist order finding that SSBT violated Section 34(b) of the Investment Company Act and caused violations of Section 31(a) of the Act and Rule 31a-1(b) in its maintenance of certain records of foreign currency trades with registered investment companies who were also custody clients of SSBT during 2006-2009.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: SSBT admitted certain facts concerning its FX pricing practices, but neither admitted nor denied the findings, and paid disgorgement of $75 million, $17.4 million interest, and a civil penalty in the amount of $75 million.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to close out a fail to deliver position at a registered clearing agency in an equity security resulting from a long sale and failing to maintain adequate supervisory system, procedures and training related to fail to deliver transactions.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $47,250.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to file timely financial statements.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, and paid a fine of $25,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Chicago Mercantile Exchange
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failure to file timely financial statements and failure to submit a subordinated debt loan agreement for approval in violation of CME Rule 970 A 2.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM agreed to a monetary fine of $25,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)

ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failure to report to TRACE the correct time of execution and within 15 minutes of execution for 38  fixed income transactions in accordance with FINRA Rules 6730(c)(8) and 6730(a).

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failing to prepare accurate bank reconciliations and failure to maintain adequate supervision of preparation and maintenance of operating bank account and general ledger, as well as related reconciliations in violation of Securities Exchange Act Rules 15c3-1(c)(2)(iv)021, 15c3-3, 17a-3, FINRA Rule 4523, NASD Rules 3010(a) and 3110(a).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, was censured and paid a fine of $125,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Chicago Mercantile Exchange
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for submitting messages to Globex using non-unique Tag50 IDs and submitting messages to Globex with the incorrect Manual Order Identifier (Tag 1028) in violation of Rule 576 (Identification of Globex Terminal Operators).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM agreed to a fine of $2,500.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for certain 2008 TRACE reporting violations under NASD Rules 2010, 2110, 3010, 3110, and 3360, SEC Rule 17a-3, and FINRA Rules 4560, 6730(a) and 6730(c)(8).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent and paid a fine of $52,500.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failure to report to TRACE the correct time of trade execution for certain transactions and for inadequate written supervisory procedures with respect thereto.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the allegations, SSGM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent, and paid a fine of $35,000.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Global Markets, LLC (SSGM)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: FINRA
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSGM was cited for failure to report to TRACE certain transactions within 15 minutes of execution and the correct time of execution as required by FINRA rules 6730(a) and (c)8.  SSgM was also cited for failure to show the correct time of execution on the memoranda of certain brokerage orders as required by SEC Rule 17a-3 and FINRA Rule 4511(a).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Without admitting or denying the findings, SSgM signed an Acceptance, Waiver and Consent and paid a fine of $22,500.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SEC is conducting an investigation into the overcharging of six clients of the State Street UK transition management business during 2010 and 2011.  See UK FCA investigation and penalty described in 10(f).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: State Street is in discussions with the SEC Staff and has reached an agreement in principle to pay a $32.3 million penalty. Resolution is subject to completion of negotiations on other settlement terms and review and consideration by the SEC.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Federal Reserve Bank and Massachusetts Division of Banks
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSBT entered into a written agreement with the Federal Reserve Bank and the Massachusetts Division of Banks relating to deficiencies identified in SSBTs compliance programs with the requirements of the Bank Secrecy Act, anti money laundering regulations and US economic sanctions regulations of the Office of Foreign Assets control.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Under the agreement, SSBT will implement improvements to its compliance programs and will retain an independent firm to conduct a review of account and transaction activity covering a prior three month period.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Corporation (SSC) and State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
ACTIONTITLE: Plymouth County Retirement System v State Street Corporation et al
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: N/A
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSC has received a purported class action demand letter alleging that its invoicing practices were unfair and deceptive under Massachusetts law.  The demand letter also challenges the methodology used by SSC to calculate the amounts it will reimburse affected customers.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The demand letter seeks damages and other remedies.

ENTITYNAME: State Street Bank and Trust Company (SSBT)
ACTIONTITLE: In the Matter of State Street Bank and Trust Company (GovEx)
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: SEC
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: SSBT is cooperating in an ongoing inquiry by the SEC relating to the GovEx electronic trading platform, which was operated by SSBT from September 2009 to July 2015. The subjects of the inquiry are communications by SSBT related to volume, pricing and functionalities of the platform.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: If the SEC pursues an enforcement action against SSBT, it may seek monetary or other penalties or remedies.

ENTITYNAME: Nicholas Kaiser and Phelps McIlvaine
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: NASDR, District 3- Seattle
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Investors National (a subsidiary of Saturna Capital Corporation) failed to ensure that a properly qualified Municipal Securities Principal was registered with Investors National from March 1995 to October 1996.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A censure of Investors National (and two of its principals), and a joint and several fine of $2500. Matter was resolved by Acceptance, Waiver & Consent (AWC) on 8/4/1997.

ENTITYNAME: CIBC Mellon Trust Company
ACTIONTITLE: U.S. Securitities and Exchange Commission v. CIBC Mellon Trust Company
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: CIBC Mellon Trust Company ('CMTC'), a transfer agent that is an affiliate of Registrant by virtue of Mellon Canada Holding Company's 50 percent interest in the joint venture, submitted a Consent to Entry of Judgment (the 'Consent'), which was presented by the SEC in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (the 'Court') on February 16, 2005. In the Consent, and solely for the purpose of the injunctive action and any other proceedings arising out of the SEC's investigation brought by or on behalf of the SEC or to which the SEC is a party, CMTC consented to the entry of Final Judgment as to Defendant CMTC (the 'Final Judgment') without admitting or denying the matters set forth therein (other than those relating to the jurisdiction of the Court and the subject matter of the action). The Final Judgment, entered on Feb. 24, 2005, resolved the allegations that CMTC had failed to register as a transfer agent with the SEC, that it had issued 'legend free' stock certificates of a company whose shares were not registered with the SEC, that one of its managers had accepted payments of stock from that company's officers to issue the certificates, and that it had acted as an unregistered broker or dealer in connection with its stock plan administration business. CMTC was permanently enjoined from prescribed violations of Securities Act Section 5, Exchange Act Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, Exchange Act Section 15(a), Exchange Act Section 17A(c)(1), and from aiding and abetting future violations of Exchange Act Section 10(b) or Rule 10b-5. CMTC also agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of $5 million and disgorgement of $889,773 and prejudgment interest of $140,270. Payment was made on March 4, 2005. CMTC also consented, without admitting or denying the SEC complaint's allegations, to the entry of an SEC administrative order based on the Final Judgment on March 2, 2005 (the 'Order'). Pursuant to the Order, CMTC was censured and agreed to an undertaking to engage an independent consultant to review its relevant businesses and procedures. This matter responds to items 10B(1) and 10C(2).
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: Entry of Judgment on consent.  See item (v) above for detail.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon (the 'Bank')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Securities and Exchange Commission (the 'SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On June 13, 2016, the SEC finalized a settlement with the Bank, an affiliate of the Registrant, relating to the Bank's standing instruction foreign exchange ('FX') program. The SEC instituted a settled administrative proceeding against the Bank, finding that the Bank violated Section 34(b) of the Investment Company Act of 1940, and caused violations of Section 31(a) of the act and Rule 31a-1(b) thereunder. The order requires the Bank to cease and desist from such violations, pay a $30 million civil penalty, and disgorge $133,022,207 which is deemed satisfied by the Bank's prior payments in related settlements with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and The New York Attorney General. The order also requires the Bank to report on its remediation and implementation of compliance measures relating to its standing instruction FX programs offered to registered investment adviser custodial clients.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(1)(v) above.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufscht -Germany
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: Bundesanstalt fur Finanzdienstleistungsaufscht (the BaFin), the financial supervisory authority in Germany, alleged that The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (BNY Mellon) violated certain supervisory duties under the Securities Trading Act (the Act). Under this Act, anyone whose shareholding in a German issuer reaches, exceeds or falls below 3%, 5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 30%, 50% or 75% of the voting rights shall notify the issuer and the BaFin, without undue delay, and within four trading days at the latest. The BaFin alleged that: (1) notifications sent by BNY Mellon on behalf of certain subsidiaries to a German issuer and the BaFin of the reduction of its voting shares in the issuer below the 3% threshold was one month late and (2) BNY Mellon failed to take the supervisory measures required under the Act to prevent contravention of the shareholding notice obligations by its subsidiaries. On May 12, 2011, the BaFin issued an administrative order that: (1) determined that BNY Mellon negligently failed to comply with the supervisory requirements with respect to its subsidiaries in order to ensure compliance with the notification deadlines and (2) imposed against BNY Mellon an administrative fine of EUR 22,500.00 (approx. $31,725) and a fee (for procedural costs) of EUR 1,125.00 (approx. $1,586). BNY Mellon made payment effective May 27, 2011.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See response in 10(f)(v)

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon - London Branch ('BNYM')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.K. Financial Conduct Authority
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority alleged that BNYM failed to comply with certain rules set forth in the U.K. Clients Assets Sourcebook, which sets forth the regime in the U.K. for the protection of client interests.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: BNY Mellon entered into a settlement agreement with the UK Financial Conduct Authority (the 'FCA') on March 6, 2015, and the FCA issued its Final Notice, in which the 126 million pounds (approx. $188M) fine was imposed, on April 14, 2015.

ENTITYNAME: Dreyfus Service Organization, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: Proceeding by the Commissioner of Banking and Ins. State of NJ Ref. No. 8059711
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, Trenton, New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged that Dreyfus Service Organization ('DSO') between June 2002 and November 2002 'caused, permitted or was otherwise responsible for allowing an employee to solicit and write eight New Jersey annuity contracts without the benefit of a current license.'  DSO had an employee with a non-resident NJ insurance license which had expired and was later reinstated.  The sales were made during the period when the employee's license was inactive, although DSO had reason to believe the license was, in fact, active.  Without admitting or denying any violation of the insurance statutes or regulations or any wrongdoing, DSO consented to an administrative sanction in the amount of $4000.00 to fully and completely resolve the matter.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(d)(4)(v) above.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon ('BNYM')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System ('BGFRS')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On 9/22/08, BNYM borrowed from the Boston Federal Reserve Bank under the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility ('AMLF') program. It was alleged that due to a failure in its internal processes at the time, a portion of the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper ('ABCP') collateral pledged by BNYM was ineligible under the terms of the AMLF. As a result, BNYM received more in the AMLF loans proceeds than it otherwise would have been advanced, based upon the eligible ABCP collateral pledged.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The BGFRS and BNYM have mutually agreed to enter into a combined Order to Cease & Desist and Order of Assessment of a Civil Monetary Penalty of $6,000,000.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon ('BNYM')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System ('BGFRS')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: On 9/22/08, BNYM borrowed from the Boston Federal Reserve Bank under the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility ('AMLF') program. It was alleged that due to a failure in its internal processes at the time, a portion of the Asset-Backed Commercial Paper ('ABCP') collateral pledged by BNYM was ineligible under the terms of the AMLF. As a result, BNYM received more in the AMLF loans proceeds than it otherwise would have been advanced, based upon the eligible ABCP collateral pledged.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: The BGFRS and BNYM have mutually agreed to enter into a combined Order to Cease & Desist and Order of Assessment of a Civil Monetary Penalty of $6,000,000.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation ('BNY Mellon')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Securities and Exchange Commission (the 'SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC Staff alleged violations of Sections 13(b)(2)(A) & (B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for books and records and internal regulatory accounting control deficiencies in connection with the calculation of risk-based regulatory capital ratios presented in annual and quarterly reports filed with the SEC.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: A civil money penalty in the amount of $6,600,000 was ordered to be paid by BNY Mellon.  BNY Mellon will effect payment on a date TBD.

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon (the 'Bank')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: The Securities and Exchange Commission (the 'SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: See 10(c)(1)(v) above
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(1)(vi) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation ('BNY Mellon')
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ('SEC')
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC Staff alleged violations of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in connection with the provision of a limited number of internships to relatives of sovereign wealth fund officials.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: An order was issued against BNY Mellon in the amount of $14,800,000, consisting of disgorgement fees of $8,300,000, prejudgment interest of $1,500,000 and a civil monetary penalty in the amount of $5,000,000. BNY Mellon effected payment on August 24, 2015

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that from at least January 1, 2003 through June 30, 2004, in connection with certain auctions, The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank on New York) ('BNY') accepted initial or revised bids after submission deadlines and allowed broker-dealers to intervene in auctions. In certain instances, this conduct also affected the rate paid on the auction rate securities. As a result, BNY caused violations of section 17(a)(2) of the Securities Act.  BNY was required to make certain disclosures regarding its material auction practices and procedures; and not later than 6 months after the date of this order, unless otherwise extended by the Staff of the Commission for good cause shown, have its CEO or General Counsel certify in writing to the Staff of the Commission that BNY has implemented procedures. In addition, BNY paid a monetary settlement in the amount of $750,000.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: The Bank of New York Mellon
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: The SEC alleged that The Bank of New York Mellon (formerly, The Bank of New York) ('BNY') failed as a transfer agent to exercise reasonable care to ascertain the correct addresses of lost security holders and escheated assets belonging to those security holders to various states. As a result, BNY entered into an agreement to offer payment to certain security holders for property escheated erroneously (while reserving the right to pursue their claim for repayment with the State to which the property was escheated).  In addition, BNY paid a penalty of $250,000 and agreed to the retention of an independent consultant to review and evaluate certain of the Bank's policies and procedures.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(c)(2)(v) above

ENTITYNAME: Dreyfus Service Organization, Inc.
ACTIONTITLE: Proceeding by the Commissioner of Banking and Ins. State of NJ Ref. No. 8059711
COURTORBODYNAMEANDLOCATION: State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, Trenton, New Jersey
ACTIONDESCRIPTION: It was alleged that Dreyfus Service Organization ('DSO') between June 2002 and November 2002 'caused, permitted or was otherwise responsible for allowing an employee to solicit and write eight New Jersey annuity contracts without the benefit of a current license.' DSO had an employee with a non-resident NJ insurance license which had expired and was later reinstated. The sales were made during the period when the employee's license was inactive, although DSO had reason to believe the license was, in fact, active. Without admitting or denying any violation of the insurance statutes or regulations or any wrongdoing, DSO consented to an administrative sanction in the amount of $4000.00 to fully and completely resolve the matter.
DISPOSITIONOFPROCEEDING: See 10(d)(4)(v) above.
